But the orator, since it is he whom we are studying‚ I myself do not picture as Crassus did, who I thought included, under the single vocation and title of orator, omni- science in every topic and every art: in fact Ι take him to be a man who can use language agreeable to the ear, and arguments suited to convince, in law—court disputes and in debates of public business. Such a man I call an orator, and would have him endowed besides with intonation, delivery and a certain charm.
